title: Erdős Problem #839: Sequences Avoiding Consecutive-Term Sums
description: For sequences where no term is a sum of consecutive earlier terms: is lim sup(aₙ/n) = ∞? Does the logarithmic density vanish? Upper density can reach 19/36 (Freud), disproving Erdős's 1/2 conjecture. Open.

references: Erdős: original questions on growth rate and density

sections.title: Definitions
sections.summary: Consecutive sums, sum-avoiding sequences, and valid sequences.

sections.title: Growth Rate Questions
sections.summary: Question 1: lim sup(aₙ/n) = ∞? Question 2: logarithmic density → 0?

sections.title: Known Results
sections.summary: lim inf(aₙ/n) can be finite, reciprocal sums ≥ c·log log x.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about sequences where no term is the sum of consecutive earlier terms. He conjectured that such sequences must be sparse (lim sup aₙ/n = ∞) and have vanishing logarithmic density. He also conjectured the upper density is at most 1/2, which Freud disproved with a construction achieving 19/36.
overview.problemStatement: Let 1 ≤ a₁ < a₂ < ... be integers where no aₘ equals aᵢ + aᵢ₊₁ + ... + aⱼ for i ≤ j < m. (1) Is lim sup(aₙ/n) = ∞? (2) Does (1/log x)·Σ_{aₙ<x} 1/aₙ → 0?
overview.proofStrategy: We define consecutive-term sum avoidance, formalize both growth-rate questions, record Erdős's observations about achievable lower bounds, and state Freud's counterexample showing upper density can exceed 1/2.
keyInsights: Consecutive-sum avoidance is stronger than avoiding all subset sums — it only forbids contiguous blocks
lim inf(aₙ/n) < ∞ is achievable, so the sequence can be dense infinitely often
Erdős's conjecture that upper density ≤ 1/2 was disproved by Freud (19/36 ≈ 0.528)
The reciprocal sum Σ 1/aₙ can grow at least as c·log log x

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #839 poses two open questions about the sparsity of sequences avoiding consecutive-term sums. While Freud disproved the upper density conjecture, both growth-rate questions remain unresolved.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the structure of additive avoidance constraints, connecting to Sidon sets, sum-free sets, and additive number theory more broadly.
openQuestions: Is lim sup(aₙ/n) = ∞ for all valid sequences?
Does the logarithmic density (1/log x)·Σ 1/aₙ vanish?
What is the maximum possible upper density of a valid sequence?
Is Freud's 19/36 the supremum, or can it be improved?
